items.title: Gout Gout qualifies for 200m semifinals at World Athletics Championships in Tokyo
items.summary: Sprint sensation Gout Gout has lived up to the hype by qualifying for the 200m semi-finals at the world championships.

items.title: Israel opens 'temporary' new route out of Gaza City for 48 hours as tanks advance
items.summary: An Israeli official said military operations were focused on getting civilians to head south and that fighting would intensify over the next month or two.

items.title: Australia's newest citizens welcomed in ceremonies on Australian Citizenship Day
items.summary: Thousands are celebrating becoming new Australians, as local councils hosted ceremonies around the country for Australian Citizenship Day. SBS spoke to some of the new citizens.

items.title: The bank of mum and dad helping first home buyers, & investors look to US Federal Reserve
items.summary: Parents and grandparents are increasingly offering financial assistance to family members with 20 per cent saying they provided help in the last quarter, so SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gon√ßalves speaks with UBS Economist Stephen Wu to find out to what extent they're helping. Plus Kyle Rodda from capital.com looks through the day's sharemarket action and previews the Federal Reserve's interest rate decision.

items.title: Charlie Kirk killing suspect could face death penalty after being formally charged with murder
items.summary: The 22-year-old suspected of killing conservative activist Charlie Kirk has been formally charged with capital murder. Meanwhile, the fallout from the assassination continues to reverberate across the United States, in the courts, in politics, and in public debate.

items.title: No deal: Albanese leaves empty-handed after PNG delays defence pact
items.summary: The Prime Minister is leaving Papua New Guinea empty-handed after a landmark security agreement wasn't signed in the final hours. The delayed deal comes less than two weeks after a similar defence with Vanuatu was delayed over concerns it will affect their other relationships.

items.title: UN commission says Israel committed genocide; thousands flee Israeli assault on Gaza City
items.summary: Israel has intensified its ground assault on Gaza City just hours after a UN committee released a report adding to widespread accusations of genocide. The Australian government is among a growing chorus of countries - and hostage families - calling for Israel to change course.

items.title: Charlie Kirk's alleged killer has been charged. Trump's base has its sights on a different target
items.summary: Fears are growing of a looming crackdown on Donald Trump's perceived political opponents after the US president and members of his administration warned the "radical left" would face consequences for the assassination of right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk.

items.title: PM says defence deal with PNG to be signed within weeks | Evening News Bulletin 17 September 2025
items.summary: Anthony Albanese says he is confident a defence pact with Papua New Guinea is weeks away from being signed; Australia's newest citizens welcomed in ceremonies held around the country; and Peter Bol shattered after being edged out in the heats at the World Athletics Championships.

items.title: Four arrested after Epstein, Trump images projected on castle ahead of president's visit
items.summary: Four adults were arrested on suspicion of malicious communications after protesters unfurled a massive banner featuring a photograph of Trump and Epstein near Windsor Castle, and later projected several images of the pair onto one of its towers.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 17 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Albanese leaves PNG without the desired defence pact | Midday News Bulletin 17 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Anthony Albanese to leave Papua New Guinea without the defence pact he's been seeking; Israel's ground offensive in Gaza begins, despite a UN commission accusing it of genocide there; and in football, Real Madrid starts the Champions League with a win.

items.title: Hollywood pays tribute to Robert Redford after acting legend's death
items.summary: Hollywood actors have reflected on Robert Redford's legacy after the actor died aged 89.

items.title: Australia-PNG defence pact on hold, but PM insists it'll still be inked
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese was expected to sign the landmark defence treaty while visiting Papua New Guinea.

items.title: Chalmers reacts to Trump's rebuke as ABC journalist says president was 'feisty'
items.summary: The ABC's Americas editor John Lyons joked he would have to "brace himself" after US President Donald Trump said he was going to tell Prime Minister Anthony Albanese about him.

items.title: Israel has committed genocide in Gaza, UN inquiry finds | Morning News Bulletin 17 September 2025
items.summary: A UN committee finds Israel is committing genocide in a new report; Donald Trump says he expects to meet Anthony Albanese soon; Gout Gout prepares to make his senior debut at the World Athletics Championships.

items.title: 'I had enough of his hatred': Texts reveal motive as charges filed in Charlie Kirk murder
items.summary: Utah prosecutors have charged 22-year-old Tyler Robinson with the murder of right-wing activist Charlie Kirk, announcing plans to seek the death penalty.

items.title: When Andrea‚Äôs husband died, their blended family was 'instantaneously decimated'
items.summary: Maintaining contact with step or blended family after a separation can be difficult and give rise to mixed emotions ‚Äî especially when there are no legal responsibilities between stepparents and stepchildren.

items.title: Modified and dangerous: The popular 'illegal motorbikes' on Australia's roads
items.summary: Modified e-bikes that can run well over their legal speed limit are causing serious injuries and even deaths ‚Äî is it time for Australia to crack down?

items.title: Cocaine, cartels, and questions: Concerns over Trump's drug boat 'hunt'
items.summary: The US has carried out deadly strikes on Venezuelan boats it alleges carried 'narcoterrorists'. But are these killings lawful? And why is the US turning its focus to the South American nation?

items.title: 'Carnage': Israel launches major ground offensive in Gaza
items.summary: The ground incursion into Gaza City comes as a UN independent commission concluded in a report that Israel has committed genocide in Gaza.

items.title: 'As data-minimising as possible': under-16 social media ban guidelines published
items.summary: Australia's eSafety commissioner has published regulatory guidelines for social media platforms, giving effect to the government's under-16 social media ban. While the ban won't be in place until December 10th, the eSafety commissioner says they want it to be as minimally invasive as possible. Under the guidance, social media platforms will not have to verify the age of every user on their platforms.

items.title: Deep rifts widen further within Coalition under climate change pressure
items.summary: Liberal senator Jonathan Duniam has warned the Coalition will face a "mass exodus" from its frontbench if it adopts a net zero policy without caveats, handing Opposition leader Sussan Ley a fresh test over the party's stance on climate action. The warning comes a day after Liberal MP Andrew Hastie threatened to quit the party if it pursued a policy of net zero emissions by 2050.

items.title: Israel has committed genocide against Palestinians in Gaza, UN inquiry finds
items.summary: The UN commission of inquiry concluded that Israeli authorities and forces had, since October 2023, committed "four of the five genocidal acts" listed in the 1948 Genocide Convention.

items.title: Australian dollar hits a 10 month high against the US
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gon√ßalves takes a look at the driving forces in the currency markets with Chris Weston from Pepperstone and previews the US Federal Reserve's Thursday morning interest rate decision.

items.title: PM 'confident' as PNG delays signing defence pact | Evening News Bulletin 16 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, the Prime Minister gives assurances as Papua New Guinea delays signing a new security pact, three charged over alleged assisted suicides, as police open probes into previous deaths. And in athletics, Australia's Jessica Hull confident she could take first in the 1500 metres at tonight's World Championships.

items.title: Cash-for-votes, deepfakes and propaganda: Russia's latest bid for influence
items.summary: As Russia's neighbour prepares to head to the polls, a pro-Russian alliance appears to be on the rise thanks, in part, to a disinformation and propaganda campaign some believe is backed by the Kremlin.

items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Doctor 'furious' after being told to leave Virgin Australia lounge for expressing breast milk
items.summary: Virgin Australia has apologised, saying the way the matter was handled "fell short" of its standards.

items.title: What social media platforms will ‚Äî and won't ‚Äî have to do under Australia's under-16s ban
items.summary: Australia's eSafety commissioner has unveiled guidelines for social media companies to comply with age restriction laws that will come into effect on 10 December. Here's what we know.

items.title: Moldova heads to an election: but will Russian interference change the result?
items.summary: Voters in Moldova head to the polls later this month, in an election authorities warn is being undermined by a campaign of vote buying and digital propaganda, orchestrated by Moscow. Independent investigators believe up to 40% of votes will be the result of the Russian interference campaign, which seeks to promote pro-Kremlin parties and slow Moldova‚Äôs plans to join the European Union.

items.title: 'Israel is fighting a war of slavery': Strong criticism from emergency summit in Qatar
items.summary: Arab and Islamic leaders have met in Doha following Israel‚Äôs strike that killed Hamas officials and a Qatari security officer. Qatar‚Äôs Emir accused Israel of seeking dominance, while Iran, Turkey and Egypt called for sanctions, isolation and regional defence coordination.

items.title: Political fallout over climate action | Midday News Bulletin 16 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Coalition MPs threaten to quit over emissions targets, in the wake of a bombshell climate report, a former British paratrooper pleads not guilty to murder in Northern Ireland's Bloody Sunday killings. And in sport, the AFL is to revive its State of Origin series.

items.title: One man dead, several police injured after gas leak at Sydney restaurant
items.summary: The police had tried to help a man who was found unconscious in the restaurant.

items.title: One man dead, several police injured after gas leak at Sydney restaurant
items.summary: The police had tried to help a man who was found unconscious in the restaurant.

items.title: Liberal senator warns of 'mass exodus' from Coalition frontbench over net zero
items.summary: The Liberal party is once again at loggerheads over the party's stance on net zero, with another frontbencher warning against adopting a policy "at any cost".

items.title: How to watch Gout Gout's senior debut at the World Athletics Championships
items.summary: The Australian sprinting sensation will make his senior international debut in Tokyo on Wednesday night. Here's what you need to know.

items.title: Kurtis Marschall takes pole vault bronze for Australia at World Athletics Championships 2025
items.summary: Pole vaulter Kurtis Marschall has won Australia's first medal of the Tokyo world championships and Mondo Duplantis has broken his own world record in the event.

items.title: Israel threatens Hamas 'wherever they are' as Arab leaders review ties after Qatar attack
items.summary: Arab and Muslim leaders called for a review of ties with Israel after emergency talks in Doha following last week's strike in the Qatari capital.

items.title: US, China reach 'framework' deal on TikTok ownership ahead of Trump's call with Xi
items.summary: The United States and China have reached a framework agreement to shift TikTok to US-controlled ownership, with final confirmation expected in a call between Donald Trump and Xi Jinping.

items.title: Baby killed in a tragic carpark accident in Sydney | Morning Bulletin 16 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, A five month old baby killed in a tragic carpark accident in Sydney; Qatar hosts an emergency summit after an Israeli strike on Hamas in Doha; and in sport, Spain calls for Israel to be banned from future sporting events.

items.title: Inside the 'hyper-connected' nationalist groups fuelling protests in Australia and the UK
items.summary: There is a complex picture behind the recent mobilisation of the far-right across Australia and the UK. But experts say it's happened before.

items.title: How much money do you really need to be happy? Here's what the research says
items.summary: Recent data shows that economic inequality in Australia is increasing.

items.title: Rubio says US will provide 'unwavering support' for Israel in Gaza war
items.summary: Benjamin Netanyahu said Marco Rubio's visit was a "clear message" the United States stood with Israel.

items.title: Papua New Guinea celebrates 50th anniversary of independence from Australia
items.summary: Papua New Guinea is celebrating the 50th anniversary of its independence from Australia. The occasion is being marked with festivities in the capital Port Moresby as well as Papua New Guinean communities in Australia. The ongoing relationship remains crucial to both counties - even more so with the signing of an landmark defence agreement in Port Moresby.

items.title: Experts warn rates double for some sexually transmitted infections
items.summary: The latest snapshot of sexually transmitted infections in Australia shows some alarming trends over the past 10 years. A report from the University of New South Wales' Kirby Institute suggests testing gaps and accessibility issues are contributing to a rise in cases.

items.title: ANZ cops $240m fine for widespread misconduct
items.summary: The Australian share market has begun the week lower, despite optimism ahead of the US Federal Reserve‚Äôs expected interest rate cut this week. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Macquarie Private Bank Division Director Martin Lakos. Plus, ANZ has been fined $240 million for what ASIC has called widespread misconduct, including allegations of failing to respond to customer hardship notices and failing to refund fees charged to thousands of dead customers. For more, Asha Abdi spoke with Professor Allan Fels from the University of Melbourne.

items.title: 'We take it very seriously': Queenslander charged over Nazi salute at AFL game
items.summary: A spectator has received a lifetime AFL ban after being accused of performing a Nazi salute at a major finals clash.

items.title: 'No Australian spared': National Climate Risk Assessment delivers dire warning
items.summary: Coastal hazards driven by climate change could put three million people at risk by 2090 if Australia warms by 3 degrees, according to a major body of new climate research released by the federal government. The National Climate Risk Assessment has been released, as the government prepares the ground to announce its carbon emissions reduction target for 2035.

items.title: Trillions of dollars at risk due to climate change | Evening News Bulletin 15 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Australia faces a wealth loss of more than 4 trillion dollars due to climate change, Victoria's Premier lands in China, promoting direct links with the state. And in sport, tensions as fierce rivals India beats Pakistan at a T20 match in the Asia Cup.

items.title: Adolescence star Owen Cooper becomes youngest male actor to win an Emmy
items.summary: The four-part series he starred in recorded 140 million views in its first three months on Netflix, and drew rave reviews.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 15th September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Urgent calls for the federal government to adopt recommendations to combat Islamophobia
items.summary: Prominent calls are being made for the federal government to adopt newly-introduced recommendations, following a report by the government-appointed Envoy to Combat Islamophobia. It follows data from the Islamophobia Register Australia, revealing a 530 per cent increase in incidents since October 7, 2023.

items.title: Arab leaders urge international community to stop applying 'double standards' to Israel
items.summary: An Israeli strike on Doha last week has set off a wave of condemnation, with Arab and Islamic leaders gathering in Qatar to arrive at a united response. Israel, meanwhile, is standing firm, deepening its alliance with Washington as the war in Gaza rages on.

items.title: "widespread misconduct" ANZ hit with major fine | Midday News Bulletin 15 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, ANZ admits to misconduct that impacted nearly 65 thousand customers, new findings that climate change could threaten the lives of three million Australians by 2090. And in football, a stellar return to the game for Sam Kerr, scoring a 100th goal for Chelsea.

items.title: No Australians immune: What 2050 and beyond will look like for your city
items.summary: Australia is likely to experience more intense and extreme climate hazards ‚Äî in some cases where people and places haven't experienced them before.

items.title: 'Does my head in': Albanese closes electorate office, blaming pro-Palestinian protesters
items.summary: Announcing the closure, the prime minister cited protesters who have "repeatedly blocked access" to the electorate office over the past two years.

items.title: 'A real slap in the face': ANZ to be handed record fine for misconduct
items.summary: The penalties the financial watchdog and ANZ will request include a record $80 million fine for unconscionable conduct.

items.title: Iranian women find new ways to resist three years on from Mahsa Amini's death
items.summary: In Iran, mandatory hijab laws sparked nationwide protests three years ago over death in custody of Mahsa Jina Amini. While the presence of morality police on the streets has declined, the regime says it is instead using digital tools such as citizen-watch apps, drones and facial recognition to enforce its crackdown. But women are finding new ways to resist.

items.title: Suspect in Charlie Kirk shooting 'not cooperating' with investigators, Utah governor says
items.summary: Police investigating Tyler Robinson, the Utah man suspected of shooting right-wing commentator Charlie Kirk, have yet to establish a motive for the killing. Utah's governor said he would be formally charged on Tuesday.

items.title: Albanese says Australia-PNG defence treaty on par with US and New Zealand
items.summary: More detail will be provided once the defence agreement is signed on Wednesday, the prime minister said.

items.title: Albanese says Australia-PNG defence treaty on par with US and New Zealand
items.summary: More detail will be provided once the defence agreement is signed on Wednesday, the prime minister said.

items.title: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese set to sign a defence pact with PNG | Morning Bulletin 15 September 2025
items.summary: In this bulletin, Australia's Prime Minister will be signing a defence pact with Papua New Guinea; Leaders gather in Qatar's capital to discuss Israel's airstrikes on Doha; and in sport, Final stage of Vuelta a Espana abandoned as protestors block the circuit.

items.title: Qatari prime minister says 'time has come to punish Israel' after unprecedented strike on Doha
items.summary: Sheikh Mohammed bin Abdulrahman Al Thani has called on the world to reject what he called "double standards" after an Israeli strike on Doha, as Arab and Islamic leaders attend an emergency summit.

items.title: Cali lives a proud 'trad life'. But a former tradwife says the lifestyle left her 'dead inside'
items.summary: 'Tradwife' influencers like Cali believe a woman‚Äôs most important roles are as a wife and a mother ‚Äî and they also believe in sharing that lifestyle to their online followers. But a former tradwife says the growing popularity of this content is extremely concerning.

items.title: Rubio reiterates unwavering US support for Israel as dozens killed in Gaza City offensive
items.summary: The US secretary of state said Israel's recent airstrike in Qatar was "not going to change the nature of our relationship with the Israelis" but the two nations were "going to have to talk about" its impact on Gaza ceasefire negotiations.

items.title: This common bathroom habit could be doing you more damage than you think
items.summary: Using your phone on the throne could lead to an increased risk of haemorrhoids, according to a new study, but some experts say it's not the full story.

items.title: Australia announces more defence funding| Evening News Bulletin 14 September 2025
items.summary: Australia's AUKUS partners will benefit from a $12 billion boost to defence spending; nine people charged in raids targeting online child abuse; and Australian sprinter Torrie Lewis through to the 100m semi final at the World Athletics Championships.

items.title: Romania scrambles fighter jets in response to Russian drones | Midday News Bulletin 14 September 2025
items.summary: The government announces $1.2 billion in defence spending linked to the AUKUS agreement; Romania scrambles fighter jets in response to Russian drones; and in sport, the Lions book their spot in the AFL preliminary finals.

items.title: Government to spend $12 billion on 'world-class' AUKUS defence facility in WA
items.summary: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese has announced a $12 billion investment into a Western Australian defence precinct, which is set to bolster Australia's ability to build warships and host nuclear-powered submarines.

items.title: Torrie Lewis breaks her own Australian 100m record at World Athletics Championships 2025
items.summary: Sprint queen Torrie Lewis has given Australia a flying start to the world athletics championships with a record-breaking 100m run.

items.title: INTERVIEW: The new Aged Care Act and the 'unintended consequences' preventing transformational change
items.summary: A new Aged Care Act is weeks away from coming into effect, but there are aspects that has the Inspector-General of Aged Care concerned.

items.title: Competing protests in Australia's major cities | Morning News Bulletin 14 September 2025
items.summary: Police intervene to stop protesters clashing in Melbourne; a vigil held for slain conservative activist Charlie Kirk; and in sport, Alex de Minaur crashes out of the Davis Cup in Sydney.

items.title: Loo scrolling: Study investigates link between this bathroom habit and a painful health condition
items.summary: Using your phone while on the toilet could be linked to an increased chance of haemorrhoids, according to a study from the United States. So if you're a loo scroller, the extra time spent on the toilet could be doing you more harm than good.

items.title: What next for the Coalition after its 'entirely unedifying week'?
items.summary: Liberal senator Jane Hume says the Coalition is looking to "move on" after demoting colleague Jacinta Nampijinpa Price over controversial comments about Indian immigration. But what are the lessons the Coalition should draw from the episode?

items.title: 'I'm ready to be arrested': How women in Iran fight 'state-sanctioned sexual violence'
items.summary: Three years after the death in custody of Mahsa Jina Amini, which sparked the widespread "Woman, Life, Freedom" movement, women are still finding ways to protest against the regime's new methods of crackdown.

items.title: Nick was a 'subservient' child in church, but 'tiny little cracks' eventually shattered his faith
items.summary: It took an "unravelling" for musician Nick Carpenter to be able to reckon with his religious upbringing in America's south and find his voice in songwriting. But he still thinks about the person he could have been.

items.title: Concerns over political extremism after rival rallies held across Australia
items.summary: Politicians are warning against the risks of extremism and political violence, after rival rallies were held in Australia's capital cities and regional centres.

items.title: Protesters clash in Melbourne as rival rallies unfold across the country
items.summary: Opposing protests took place across all capital cities and some regional areas on Saturday and, as police had predicted, things got most heated in Melbourne

items.title: 'Paradigm shift': Over 2 million homes to get internet speed boost starting this weekend
items.summary: The free speed boost is one of the biggest changes to Australian internet in history, according to one expert.

items.title: PM's wardrobe malfunction and SUV diplomacy: What you missed from the Pacific summit
items.summary: Australia's fossil fuel exports remain a source of tension as Pacific leaders double down on their support for a bid to co-host global climate talks.

items.title: INTERVIEW: Supermarket sweep: How making wise choices could save you money
items.summary: Making the switch from branded products to a store's home brand alternatives could save shoppers thousands of dollars each year at checkout, according to a financial comparison website. SBS's Cameron Carr has been finding out more from Compare the Market spokesman Phillip Portman.

items.title: Bruce McAvaney on Australia's emerging athletics 'golden age' and the run that inspired us all
items.summary: Australia's "golden age" in athletics is gathering steam, esteemed sports commentator Bruce McAvaney says, as the World Athletics Championships gets underway.

items.title: $548.5 million: The price the government is willing to pay 'to avoid a public trial' of robodebt
items.summary: The robodebt class action settlement has been billed as the largest of its kind in Australian history. However, one expert argues it represents "accountability avoided", leaving questions of misfeasance unanswered.

items.title: Former Virgin CEO‚Äôs $50m payday; & is a US rate cut locked in?
items.summary: Former Virgin Australia CEO Jayne Hrdlicka is collecting a $49.9 million pay packet, which includes 10 million shares, as revealed in the company‚Äôs annual report. For more on this and the ASX-200‚Äôs performance this week, Stephanie Youssef spoke with IG Markets analyst Tony Sycamore. Plus, US inflation has risen 2.9% in August, paving the way for the first US interest rate cut of the year when the Federal Reserve meets next week. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with AMP Chief Economist Shane Oliver.

items.title: Why the final approval for North West Shelf gas plant has Indigenous groups and environmentalists worried
items.summary: The federal government has given the final approval for the Woodside North West Shelf gas project with a series of conditions. The approval comes ahead of the Albanese government's announcement of a 2035 emissions reduction target, and after Australia emphasised its commitment to tackling climate change to Pacific leaders.

items.title: Federal government approves Woodside gas project extension, with some conditions
items.summary: The country's largest gas project's potential operating life has been extended to 2070.

items.title: A 5-minute guide to the World Athletics Championships ‚Äì and how to watch from Australia
items.summary: Australia has kicked off one of its biggest track and field campaigns in history, with a record number of athletes in Tokyo to contest the 2025 World Athletics Championships.

items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Brazil's former President Bolsonaro sentenced to jail
items.summary: Brazil's former President, Jair Bolsonaro has been sentenced to prison after being convicted of plotting a coup to remain in power after losing the 2022 election. Mr Bolsonaro, who has denied any wrongdoing, has not attended the court and has only sent his lawyers.He is the first former president in the country's history to be convicted for attacking democracy.

items.title: 'Doesn't cut the mustard': Indian Australian community leaders demand Price apology
items.summary: While welcoming an apology from Opposition leader Sussan Ley, one Indian Australian community figure said "the Liberal Party has their work cut out to repair the damage" caused by senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price's comments on Indian immigration.

items.title: Former Brazilian president Jair Bolsonaro sentenced to 27 years in jail for plotting coup
items.summary: The firebrand ex-president was convicted of plotting a coup after his 2022 election loss, and accused of acting "with the purpose of eroding democracy and institutions".

items.title: Julie Bishop hits back at bullying claims and vows to stay at ANU after deputy quits
items.summary: ANU chancellor Julie Bishop has rejected bullying allegations, and has vowed to serve out her term after vice-chancellor Genevieve Bell quit following months of controversy.

items.title: Sydney sets 146-year rainfall record as severe weather eases
items.summary: Over the 24 hours to 9am on Thursday, Sydney received a total of 122mm of rain, marking its heaviest daily rainfall for September since 1879.

items.title: US stocks benefit from Oracle surge; home ownership dream slipping
items.summary: The ASX 200 has closed 0.3% lower with healthcare stocks dragging the index down, despite gains by gold miners. That‚Äôs almost despite Oracle‚Äôs shares soaring almost 40% in its best one-day performance since 1992, lifting the S&P 500 and other global markets to record highs. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Mark Gardner from MPC Markets. Plus, new analysis from Domain shows the dream of owning a home is becoming further out of reach ‚Äì with deposit hurdles, coupled with climbing house prices and mortgage repayments, driving the sharpest generational divide in decades. For more, Stephanie Youssef spoke with Domain‚Äôs research chief, Dr Nicola Powell.

items.title: What you might not know about tornadoes in Australia
items.summary: There are about 60-80 tornadoes each year in Australia, according to a meteorologist. But you're unlikely to see them.

items.title: Israel strikes Qatar, why it's been a bad week to be a PM & the real 'Succession' finale
items.summary: Israel's strike on Qatar blows up ceasefire talks, the prime ministers of Nepal, Japan and France depart in a hurry, and Albanese battles for influence in the Pacific, while Moldova battles to stop Putin‚Äôs influence ahead of elections. Plus, the Murdoch succession is finally settled.

items.title: 'I won't be silenced': Jacinta Price axed from Coalition frontbench in fallout over Indian migration remarks
items.summary: Northern Territory Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price has been removed from the Coalition frontbench, following fallout from remarks she made about Indian migrants. Sydney Lang takes a look at how the last week unfolded.

items.title: Trump 'filled with grief' over Charlie Kirk's shooting. Here's what to know about the right-wing activist
items.summary: The shooting prompted condemnation of political violence and calls for unity from US leaders across the political spectrum.

items.title: 'Wrongful act': Vanuatu warns Australia may break international law if gas project goes ahead
items.summary: A senior Pacific minister has warned Australia's energy transition is no longer defensible, following a landmark legal ruling.

items.title: Australian-Nepalis dismayed and distressed at protests and violence in Nepal
items.summary: Nepal's Prime Minister has resigned amid anti-government protests, as demonstrators set fire to Parliament and the homes of some of the country's top political leaders. It comes as a "Gen Z" protest movement was triggered by a ban on social media, which has now been overturned. Concerns have been raised by the Nepali community in Australia, calling for peace in the country.

items.title: Will Israel's attack on Hamas officials in Qatar derail peace talks?
items.summary: Israel has struck the Qatari capital of Doha, killing five Hamas members and one Qatari security official. It has led to an outcry from Qatar, Washington, and humanitarian groups, with concern the strike will jeopardise fragile ceasefire talks.

items.title: Lifting caps from first home buyer scheme will help some but fuel wider price rise
items.summary: The federal government will expand its Home Guarantee Scheme in October, lifting income and property caps to give first-time buyers greater access, but it will also fast-track price rises, a new analysis has found.

items.summary: The federal government will expand its Home Guarantee Scheme in October, lifting income and property caps to give first-time buyers greater access, but it will also fast-track price rises, a new analysis has found.

items.title: The simple shopping swap that could save you $4,000 a year
items.summary: A comparison group examined the cost of 20 staple items at two major supermarkets. Here's what it found.

items.title: Palestinians flee Gaza City as Israel airdrops leaflets ordering them to leave
items.summary: Israel has warned it will launch a full-scale assault on Gaza City.

items.title: Gaza aid flotilla reports second attack after Tunisian authorities say 'no drones' involved in first
items.summary: The vessel was off the coast of Tunisia when it was struck by a drone, organisers of the Global Sumud Flotilla allege. Tunisian authorities have rejected the claim, saying the explosion originated inside the boat.

items.title: Gaza aid flotilla reports second attack after Tunisian authorities say 'no drones' involved in first
items.summary: The vessel was off the coast of Tunisia when it was struck by a drone, organisers of the Global Sumud Flotilla allege. Tunisian authorities have rejected the claim, saying the explosion originated inside the boat.

items.title: Albanese in the Pacific: Australia's struggle for influence ‚Äî and a key hope
items.summary: This year's Pacific Islands Forum has become a flashpoint in a broader tussle for influence between China and Australia and China and Taiwan ‚Äî and is also likely to see Australia firming up its bid to co-host a major climate conference with the Pacific in 2026.

items.title: ANZ slashes 3,500 jobs, are there more to come?
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gon√ßalves takes a closer look at ANZ's decision to cut 3,500 employees and 1,000 contractors and what it means for the sector with Nathan Zaia from Morningstar and Damien Boey from Wilson Asset Management.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 9 September 2025
items.summary: A Five minute bulletin for English language learners

items.title: Six killed, 20 injured in gun attack on East Jerusalem bus stop
items.summary: Six civilians were killed and 20 injured when two Palestinian gunmen opened fire at Jerusalem‚Äôs Ramot Junction bus stop, sending commuters running in terror. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu vowed Israel would retaliate, linking the assault to Israel‚Äôs ongoing war in Gaza, where airstrikes have destroyed dozens of high-rise buildings and a ground invasion is imminent.

items.title: Logging halted to create a koala retreat
items.summary: Australia will halt logging in a large stretch of woodland on the east coast to create a retreat for koalas, in an attempt to save the local population from extinction. The announcement, which will impact six timber mills and hundreds of workers, has caused outrage in the forestry industry. New South Wales Premier Chris Minns says the decision wasn't taken lightly and those affected will be supported.

items.title: The new regional hotspot that's seen a 1,500 per cent surge of city folk
items.summary: More city dwellers are packing their bags and heading for this regional border location, according to the latest Regional Movers Index.

items.title: Weak US data spurs rate cut chance, and the supermarkets court case
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gon√ßalves speaks with Raymond Chan from Morgans about the day's sharemarket action including the weak US jobs data, a rebalancing of the market's main indexes and the potential implications of a supermarkets underpayments court case.

items.title: Fed up with flight delays? Passengers could soon get refunds under new scheme
items.summary: The federal government aims to implement a new consumer protection scheme for travellers, which could lead to refunds and the establishment of a new complaints-handling body to address flight disruptions.

items.title: K-pop is a global phenomenon. Some of its biggest stars are from Australia
items.summary: From BLACKPINK's Ros√© to Stray Kids' Bang Chan and Felix, Australia is slowly making its presence in Korean pop music felt.

items.title: 'Not serious about ceasefire': What Russia's major attack means for the war in Ukraine
items.summary: The strike on Kyiv is less about causing damage, but more a signal from Russian President Vladimir Putin towards the West, an expert says.

items.title: Woolworths and Coles say underpayment court decision could cost them $1 billion
items.summary: The supermarket giants were found not to have complied with their obligations to keep accurate employment records and paid workers' salaries without tracking other entitlements.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 8th September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Massive drone attack on Kyiv sees Government buildings hit for the first time
items.summary: Russia‚Äôs heaviest drone and missile barrage since the war began has struck Kyiv‚Äôs Cabinet of Ministers building, leaving four dead, including an infant. Ukraine is now calling for greater global support and tougher sanctions on Russia, targeting its economy.

items.title: PM Ishiba's resignation plunges Japan into political uncertainty. Here's what happens next
items.summary: Since Shigeru Ishiba came to power in October 2024, his ruling coalition has lost its majority in both houses of parliament.

items.title: I went to search a car for drugs while on duty. What happened next made me re-evaluate my life
items.summary: Police recruitment drives in response to chronic shortages have led to more people applying to join their local force. But what were the factors that led to the shortages in the first place?

items.title: Russia unleashes biggest air barrage on Ukraine, sets government building ablaze
items.summary: Russia fired at least 810 drones and 13 missiles at Ukraine over the weekend in a new record, according to the Ukrainian air force.

items.title: Radiotherapy could save your life: dispelling the misconceptions
items.summary: Despite being a proven life-saving treatment, 1 in 5 Australians who need radiotherapy never receive it. This year, on September 7, the first-ever World Radiotherapy Awareness Day will be launched, and experts say it's an opportunity to dispel fears of the treatment.

items.title: Australian women are living longer but it's not all good news
items.summary: The Australian Institute of Health and Welfare has produced a snap shot of Women‚Äôs health across the life course. While rates of cancer have gone down for women over the last 25 years, younger women continue to experience higher rates of depression and other mental health conditions.

items.title: Hope and hate: how governments around the world are responding to 'illegal' immigration
items.summary: Recently, local news headlines have been dominated by stories about anti-immigration rallies which were held across Australia on the last day of August. But it's not just in Australia where migration has created such deep feelings - it's also an issue that has been front and centre in the US as Donald Trump fulfils his election campaign promise to carry out mass deportations. There are now at least a million fewer immigrants in the US, raising questions about the impact of their absence on key industries like agriculture and construction. Migration is also a major concern in Europe, which has long grappled with what to do with the scores of people fleeing war and poverty in their home countries. This episode of the TOO HARD BASKET focuses on these complexities.

items.title: Calls for justice after two boys stabbed to death in 'heinous' Melbourne attack
items.summary: Two boys have been killed in western Melbourne in what police suspect is a series of targeted attacks.

items.title: An Australian couple bought a French palace for $1.2m. Strangers are helping pay to restore it
items.summary: Palatial French estates are being snapped up by overseas buyers for less than a median-priced home in Sydney. But the initial outlay is usually just the start of long and expensive restoration journey. One Australian couple is funding their project in unique ways.

items.title: Melanie was sceptical of this underutilised cancer treatment. It saved her life
items.summary: One in five eligible Australian cancer patients never receives this form of treatment, according to research cited by Australian oncologists.

items.title: Beaches closed after fatal shark attack on Sydney's Northern Beaches
items.summary: Drones are being used to monitor shark activity, after a fatality on Sydney's Northern Beaches.

items.title: A surfer's death in Sydney could stir up the shark net debate. So why are they so controversial?
items.summary: A fatal shark attack on Sydney's Northern Beaches has come amid debates about the efficacy and environmental effects of shark nets. So do they actually protect swimmers, and what are the alternatives?

items.title: Loveness says she experienced racism while working as a nurse. She isn't the only one
items.summary: A new report has shed light on the experiences of racism nurses and midwives from culturally and linguistically diverse backgrounds face at work.

items.title: How a grandmother's curry tells the story of a family's migration journey
items.summary: Making a chicken curry on stage is not what you would usually expect when visiting the theatre. But for actor Joshua Jamil Hinton, it's the centrepiece of his show, due to open in Brisbane this month, telling his story of living between different cultures and grappling with his own identity.

items.title: Anti-immigration rallies ignore Australia's economic dependence on migration
items.summary: Australia in anti-immigration marches.At the heart of what organisers called the 'March for Australia' rallies was a call to end "mass migration", which protesters claimed is to blame for issues like the housing crisis and rise in cost of living. Experts say a paradox exists in the anti-immigration ideas put forward at these rallies: the very people protesters want fewer of are the ones propping up the nation's economy, workforce, and future.

items.title: Gob has been making rafts in his local river his whole life. It's never made him sick until now
items.summary: Several major rivers flowing across the border from Myanmar to Thailand have been contaminated with dangerously high levels of arsenic, threatening to cause a public health crisis.

items.title: Gob has been making rafts in his local river his whole life. It's never made him sick until now
items.summary: Several major rivers flowing across the border from Myanmar to Thailand have been contaminated with dangerously high levels of arsenic, threatening to cause a public health crisis.

items.title: ARIA chart changes to bring diversity of artists - and is the RBA done with cutting interest rates?
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gon√ßalves speaks with ARIA CEO Annabelle Herd about the changes to the ARIA Charts will highlight diverse artists in the industry, Madeline Dunk from ANZ explains why she thinks the RBA may be done cutting interest rates, and Bryce Anderson from Morningstar goes through the day's sharemarket action.

items.title: Taxpayer hit or investment? Australia's 2035 emissions target raises $500bn question
items.summary: As the government is set to announce Australia's 2035 emissions goal, the Business Council of Australia warns an ambitious goal could carry a $500 billion price tag. The Coalition says the figure represents a warning of soaring costs but others say it's an investment opportunity.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 5 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: Are neo-Nazis REALLY gaining traction in Australia?
items.summary: What was sold as a rally against mass immigration had far right ideology from the start. With neo-Nazis attending the rally and attempting to recruit new members, is far-right extremism on the rise in Australia? Dr Callum Jones and Professor Greg Barton break down what's behind these rallies, and how the government should respond.

items.title: A blood moon will soon be visible across Australia. Here's everything you need to know
items.summary: This will be the final chance for Australians to see the blood moon in 2025.

items.title: The paradox at the heart of calls to end 'mass migration' in Australia
items.summary: Community leaders say Senator Jacinta Nampijinpa Price‚Äôs comments are fuelling division, as experts warn migrants are being unfairly blamed for housing and cost of living pressures.

items.title: Xi‚Äôs 'new world order', Indonesia unrest & Thailand‚Äôs political plight
items.summary: In this episode: China‚Äôs military parade and its guests of honour the US media has dubbed ‚Äòthe Axis of Upheaval‚Äô, protesters mobilise across Indonesia as parliamentary allowances trigger mass unrest. Plus, Thailand faces yet another political crisis while environmental concerns escalate across the border in Myanmar. And the holographic warning to all would-be criminals.

items.title: Is Victoria Australia's crime state and what does it mean for insurance premiums?
items.summary: Car theft claims rose to a record $233m in Victoria last financial year, but fell in every other state so Stephanie Youssef speaks with Insuance Council of Australia CEO Andrew Hall to find out what can be done about it and what it means for premiums, plus SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gon√ßalves takes a closer look at the sharemarket with Ben Clark from TMS Private.

items.title: After Australia's economic surprise, here's what could happen to your mortgage
items.summary: Public holidays and the latest release of a video game console were all important elements in Australia's recent GDP growth, something that might mean there may not be many interest rate cuts left to come.

items.title: Liberals distance themselves from Price's Indian migrant remark as backlash grows
items.summary: The Northern Territory senator falsely claimed Labor was prioritising Indian migrants to bolster its vote. She walked back the remarks, but later said she did not believe she had anything to apologise for.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 4 September 2025
items.summary: A daily five minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: 20,000 more aged care packages more quickly after Labor agrees to Coalition deal
items.summary: 20,000 more home care packages are to be available to vulnerable older Australians after the federal government was forced to make a deal with the Coalition. It was the first major test faced by Labor since it was re-elected, which was cornered in the senate to make changes to its aged care reform policy.

items.title: ASX 200‚Äôs worst day since April; Australian economy grows faster than expected
items.summary: The Australian sharemarket has experienced its worst single-day drop since April, with all 11 sectors finishing in the red. For more, Rena Sarumpaet spoke with Perpetual‚Äôs Head of Investment Strategy, Matt Sherwood. Plus, Australia‚Äôs GDP expanded by a larger-than-expected 0.6% in the June quarter. SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Goncalves spoke with NAB Chief Economist Sally Auld about what that means for the economy.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 3 Sep 2025
items.summary: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: 'Overwhelmed with fear': Entire village wiped out, hundreds dead in Sudan landslide
items.summary: A Sudanese rebel group has appealed for international aid after a landslide buried Tarseen village in Darfur, killing up to 1,000 people and leaving only one survivor.

items.title: I'm an Australian and wanted nothing to do with religion. Here's what changed my mind
items.summary: While latest Census data pointed to a significant downward trend in Australians identifying as Christian, there was an uptick in religious diversity. Some research suggests 38 per cent of gen Z identify as spiritual and there is an increase of gen Z men turning to religion.

items.title: Gold and silver prices hit milestones & ASX hit by ex-dividend stocks
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Goncalves speaks with Josh Gilbert from eToro to find out why gold prices hit a new record while silver reached a 14 year high, plus why the ASX fell as a number of companies traded ex-dividend.

items.title: Australia's greatest threat: Not war, not terror, not pandemic... but the climate
items.summary: As the Coalition remains divided over net zero emission targets, former security leaders are warning the government that climate change poses an immediate national security threat.In the Senate, the Greens are pushing for the release of the National Climate Risk Assessment Report while Nationals Senator Matt Canavan is pushing ahead with a bill to repeal net zero.

items.title: Racism in the health sector can kill, research shows. What can be done to save lives?
items.summary: Racism is a "critical issue" in health, which can lead to a breakdown in trust between patients and healthcare workers.

items.title: Spain prepares for future extreme weather after 'environmental catastrophe'
items.summary: After a summer in which much of western and southern Europe were impacted by catastrophic fires and searing heat, Spain now forming a plan to prepare for future disasters.Scientists say action is needed to reduce emissions and increase resilience, in the face of inevitable worsening conditions.

items.title: SBS News in Easy English 2 Sep 2025
items.summary: A daily 5-minute news wrap for English learners and people with disability.

items.title: No end in sight: famine tightens its grip on Gaza as Israeli families mourn hostages
items.summary: Hungry Palestinians have queued at a soup kitchen in Khan Younis, empty pots in hand, as famine tightens its grip on Gaza. Families say aid is failing to reach them, while shortages and soaring prices have left markets bare. The United Nations says nearly half a million people in Gaza face catastrophic hunger, nearly a quarter of the territory's population.

items.title: Cap on Australia's migration numbers to stay the same, government confirms
items.summary: The government said it has undertaken consultations with the states and territories, which recommended maintaining the size and composition of the migration program.

items.title: How Australia's social media ban could make life 'a lot more difficult' for those most at risk
items.summary: Online anonymity is often a lifeline for those "most at risk" in the community. Experts say the government's proposed social media ban could cut off vulnerable people from critical digital spaces.

items.title: Aboriginal Camp Sovereignty site attacked by anti-immigration protesters
items.summary: An Aboriginal gathering place and burial ground was attacked in Melbourne on Sunday by participants in the city's anti-immigration rallies. Police are investigating the incident, which witnesses say involved self-proclaimed neo-Nazi Thomas Sewell and up to 100 others. The incident has been condemned by political leaders, with Senator Lidia Thorpe calling for a federal inquiry.

items.title: 'Wake-up call': Government urged to address rise in far-right extremism after racist rallies
items.summary: Politicians have condemned the racism and xenophobia displayed at various anti-immigration protests over the weekend. After violent clashes and a large neo-Nazi presence, the Greens are calling on the government to urgently address rising right-wing extremism in Australia.

items.title: Protesters claim high migration levels have 'torn' Australia. Here's what experts say
items.summary: Australia's migration numbers and policies were the target of March for Australia's anti-immigration rallies over the weekend. Here's what experts have to say about their claims.

items.title: Thousands rally against immigration with neo-Nazis taking the spotlight
items.summary: A wave of nation-wide anti-immigration rallies have swept Australia's capital cities, with thousands joining marches and clashing with police and counter-protesters across the country. Organisers say the events were calling for an end to what they consider "mass migration" into Australia, while neo-Nazi groups infiltrated a number of the events to stir up chaos.

items.title: 'An attack on multiculturalism': government's new Nauru deal greeted with alarm
items.summary: The Federal Government has struck a $400 million deal with Nauru that it says paves the way for deportation of the so-called NZYQ cohort. The announcement has been met with outrage from advocates, human rights lawyers, and the Greens. Critics say the deal threatens fundamental legal rights in ways that could be applied more broadly.

items.title: Sydney Marathon 2025: Records broken as Sifan Hassan, Hailemaryam Kiros win
items.summary: Dutch superstar Sifan Hassan and Ethiopia's Hailemaryam Kiros have triumphed in the Sydney marathon as Kenyan legend Eliud Kipchoge battled to ninth.

items.title: Scottish brothers reach Cairns after record-breaking row across the Pacific Ocean
items.summary: After more than four months at sea, the brothers reunited with loved ones ‚Äî along with pizza and beer ‚Äî as they reached their final destination.

items.title: Scottish brothers reach Cairns after record-breaking row across the Pacific Ocean
items.summary: After more than four months at sea, the brothers reunited with loved ones ‚Äî along with pizza and beer ‚Äî as they reached their final destination.

items.title: Khawaja's proposed Israel sports ban would violate 'equal rights', Olympic body says
items.summary: Australia's opening batsman Usman Khawaja has argued international sporting bodies should consider removing Israel, over its treatment of Palestinians in Gaza.

items.title: Why Anthony Albanese was chased by angry farmers on tractors
items.summary: Protesters at the annual Bush Summit event also used tractors and fire engines to block Victorian Premier Jacinta Allan from leaving.

items.title: Iran ambassador expelled, Trump‚Äôs military crackdown & KPop Demon Hunters
items.summary: In this episode: Australia punishes Iran after dramatic revelations in Canberra, Trump‚Äôs latest threats to set troops on more Democrat-held cities in the US, and a mass deportation pitch from the UK‚Äôs far right. Plus, why Venezuelan housewives are joining Maduro‚Äôs militia and South Korea‚Äôs supernatural export pops on global streaming.

items.title: 'It creates a worry in your head': International students plan to stay home during protests
items.summary: International education is Australia's fourth largest export, but with protests looming that demand dramatic cuts to migration, some experts think the event could "cast a shadow over the brand of Australia".

items.title: Accused cop killer Dezi Freeman is still on the run. Here's what we know about him
items.summary: The suspect behind the Porepunkah police shooting is still at large in the Victorian high country. Here's what we know about accused cop killer Dezi Freeman.

items.title: Knights of the (productivity) roundtable ft. Senator Jacqui Lambie
items.summary: A lot has happened since the last sitting week. The Prime Minister announced Australia's plan to soon recognise Palestinian statehood, and the best economic minds gathered to solve the productivity crisis. We break down why you should care about productivity at all, and Jacqui Lambie talks through her idea for a 'climate army'.

items.title: CEO Series: Wesfarmers Rob Scott calls for action on Victorian retail crime
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gon√ßalves speaks with Wesfarmers CEO Rob Scott about the company's $2.9bn profit, bonus shareholder returns and the economic environment, plus a look at the day on the sharemarket including Qantas' second best profit result ever, with Angus Geddes from Fat Prophets.

items.title: 'Incredibly alarming': Albanese's proposed rules for deporting non-citizens criticised
items.summary: Human rights lawyers are concerned about a new government proposal designed to remove legal obstacles to resettling three people in Nauru who were released as a result of the landmark "NZYQ" High Court decision.

items.title: Two dead in another US school shooting
items.summary: Two children have been killed and 17 people wounded in a Catholic school shooting in Minneapolis in the United States. Authorities say they're investigating the shooting as an act of domestic terrorism and a hate crime targeting Catholics.

items.title: Gun ownership is rising in Australia. Who owns them, and why?
items.summary: Australian gun ownership is being driven by a wide range of different influences ‚Äî many of which remain largely invisible.

items.title: FBI investigating Minneapolis school shooting as 'hate crime targeting Catholics'
items.summary: The FBI is investigating the shooting as an act of terrorism and an anti-Catholic hate crime.

items.title: FBI investigating Minneapolis school shooting as 'hate crime targeting Catholics'
items.summary: The FBI is investigating the shooting as an act of terrorism and an anti-Catholic hate crime.

items.title: 'Strong and comfortable': Mitch Brown becomes first AFL player to come out as bisexual
items.summary: Mitch Brown, the first AFL player to publicly identify as bisexual, has spoken about the fear of having his sexuality discovered while he was playing.

items.title: CEO Series: Flight Centre's Graham Turner on airfares, AI and flights to the US
items.summary: SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gon√ßalves speaks with Flight Centre CEO Graham Turner following the group's results announcement to find out more about the operating environment, airfares and consumer trends, plus Michael Wayne from Medallion Financial Group goes through the day's sharemarket action including a look at the surprise rise in inflation.

items.title: Australia's most wanted man is a sovereign citizen. What do they believe?
items.summary: Dezi Freeman has been described as a "very active sovereign citizen" who is held in "high regard" by followers of the movement that has alarmed extremism experts and law enforcement authorities.

items.title: Australia - allergy capital of the world
items.summary: The number of Australians living with allergy has doubled in nearly 20 years, according to a new report, which examines the financial and personal costs of the chronic condition. Demand for services is unprecedented, and experts warn allergy does not just impact health - it can reshape sufferers‚Äô lives.

items.title: CEO Series: Coles' Leah Weckert, Fortescue's Dino Otranto & Tyro's Jon Davey
items.summary: In this special extended edition of SBS On the Money, join SBS Finance Editor Ricardo Gon√ßalves as he speaks with Coles Group CEO Leah Weckert to find out how shoppers are feeling, Fortescue CEO Dino Otranto on how the political landscape is impacting his operations while Stephanie Youssef discusses Tyro's results with CEO Jon Davey, plus hear from Jamie Hannah from VanEck on the day on the sharemarket.

items.title: Will the First Home Buyer Guarantee scheme actually help the housing crisis?
items.summary: The government's First Home Buyer Guarantee scheme will allow thousands more renters, who are struggling to save for the usual 20 per cent home deposit, the chance to enter the property market. But experts say the scheme, brought forward by three months to October, may not be as helpful as it initially sounds. They say it leaves those using the scheme financially vulnerable, and shuts out low-income earners. And for the next generation of first home buyers, it could make their journey to property ownership even harder.

items.title: Broad consensus offers hope of fixing 'broken' environment laws
items.summary: Environment Minister Murray Watt has announced an accelerated timeframe to improve Australia's 'broken' biodiversity and conservation laws. It comes after broad consensus emerged on the urgent need for reform at the government's economic roundtable. Labor is promising stronger environmental protections and faster project approvals - but it's not the first time.
